block.p: FOR CHILDREN
Exhibitions

''CAN YOU TELL ME HOW TO GET TO SESAME STREET?'' An interactive exhibition (through Sept. 3) atthe Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Mark's Avenue, Crown Heights, recreates the set of the PBS series. Tomorrow at 11:30 a.m. and 1 p.m., Roscoe Orman, Gordon of ''Sesame Street,'' will lead a sing-along of favorite songs from the series. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 2 to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free, with suggested admission: $4.
FOR CHILDREN
Exhibitions

''CAN YOU TELL ME HOW TO GET TO SESAME STREET?'' An interactive exhibition (through Sept. 3) atthe Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Mark's Avenue, Crown Heights, recreates the set of the PBS series. Tomorrow at 11:30 a.m. and 1 p.m., Roscoe Orman, Gordon of ''Sesame Street,'' will lead a sing-along of favorite songs from the series. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 2 to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free, with suggested admission: $4.
Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Staged by the Culture Project.The elaborate puppets range from a pugnacious preschooler who has sprouted wings to a dragonfly resembling Mae West. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $12; $6 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.

''DOO-WOP DRACULA,'' a 1950's-style musical by William Electric Black about teenage love and rebellion, features a 22-member cast and 13 musical numbers. The show asks whether happiness is possible for an Italian and a Transylvanian when a plain Jane falls in love with Johnny Rave, a rebel who is dangerous not because he's a vampire but because he's different. Musical arrangements are by the reed player Harry Mann, and choreography is by Sandra Kaufmann. Sundays at 5 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays at 10 p.m. Through June 25. La Mama, 74A East Fourth Street. Tickets: $12. Information: (212) 475-7710.

''LITTLE LAME PRINCE AND THE MAGIC CLOAK,'' a musical about a young prince who must free his people from an evil uncle who has usurped the throne of his father, the good king. The story is based not on ''Hamlet'' or Disney lions, but on a 19th-century children's tale by Dinah Maria Mulock Craik that Jonathon Ward and Greg Liska have transformed into an intimate musical set in Moorish Spain. For children 5 and older. Tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m. and Sunday at 2 p.m. at the Henry Street Settlement Abrons Arts Center, 466 Grand Street, Lower East Side. Tickets: $5. Reservations advised. Information: (212) 598-0400.

''LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD/LA CAPERUCITA ROJA,'' a bilingual musical play (performed simultaneously in Spanish and English), written and directed by Manuel Antonio Moran, tells the old story with a twist. Riding Hood does not believe the wolf is a wolf, which leads the wolf to have an identity crisis. With Jose Lopez, puppeteer. Saturdays at 3:30 p.m. and Sundays at 2 p.m. Los Kabayitos Theater, second floor, 107 Suffolk Street, Lower East Side. Tickets: $10; $8 for children. Reservations: (212) 260-4080, extension 14.

''THE LAND OF SMILES,'' a musical with rod and hand puppets by the puppeteer-singer Susan Delery Whedon, with characters like Gritzi the Gremlin and Freddy the Frown. Saturdays and Sundays at noon and 1:30 p.m., through June 25. Papageno Puppet Theater, 462 Columbus Avenue, near 82nd Street, Manhattan. Tickets: $6. Reservations required: (212) 874-3297.

''LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD: THE REAL STORY'' AND ''RIP VAN WINKLE,'' a musical adaptation of the two children's fables by the Bronx Arts Ensemble and Belmont Italian-American Playhouse. Sunday at 3 p.m. at Ross Lecture Hall, the New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Kazimiroff Boulevard, the Bronx. Tickets: $7. Garden parking: $5. Information: (718) 601-7399.

''UNWANTED: THE VERY UGLY DUCKLING,'' a New Age interpretation of the Hans Christian Andersen story, in which the hero, who hatches from an adopted egg, grows up to discover both his inner beauty and his birth mother. Saturdays at 10:30 a.m. and 12:30 p.m. through July 1 at 432 West 42nd Street, Clinton. Tickets: $10. Reservations advised. Information: (212) 592-4508.
Events

''THE APPLE CORPS,'' an interactive musical production illustrating how to be alert in New York City traffic. Tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the Flushing Library, 41-17 Main Street, Queens. Free. Information: (718) 661-1212.

CENTRAL PARK CONSERVANCY. Father's Day weekend workshops tomorrow in the park from 1 to 2:30 p.m. ''Catch-and-Release,'' with fish identification and fly-tying demonstrations, at the Harlem Meer, Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, 110th Street near Fifth Avenue, (212) 860-1370. All ages. ''All Folded Up'' introduces youngsters to the art of origami, at the Henry Luce Nature Observatory at Belvedere Castle, mid-park at 79th Street, (212) 772-0210. ''It's Your Move,'' about playing chess, at the Chess and Checkers House, the Dairy, mid-park at 65th Street, (212) 794-6564. For children 6 and older. Free.

''CIRCUS AMOK.'' Jennifer Miller, the ''bearded lady'' who is the founder and director of the troupe of jugglers, acrobats, stilt walkers, divas and hoop divers called Circus Amok, leads the free urban circus in performances at Manhattan parks through June 25. Tonight at 6 in St. Mary's Park, the Bronx; tomorrow at 4 p.m. at Fort Greene Park, Brooklyn; Sunday at 4 p.m. at Prospect Park, Brooklyn; Thursday night at 6, at Marcus Garvey Park, Harlem. Information: (212) 358-5079.

''DANCING IN THE STREETS.'' The sixth annual Young People's Performance Festival will take place tomorrow at Beard Street Pier, 141 Beard Street, Red Hook, Brooklyn, with music, dance, creative workshops and exhibitions, and, of course, fresh sea breezes. Festivities begin at 10 a.m. with breakfast and a parade at Harold Ickes Park, corner of Hamilton and Van Brunt. Other activities, beginning at noon and ending at sunset, include face painting, storytelling, an aquatic dance performance, solstice rituals and water displays. Information: (212) 625-3505.

FATHER'S DAY CONCERT IN PROSPECT PARK. A sing-along concert featuring the baritone Bob Gabriel and the soprano Eva Lazar Gabriel, with the guitarist Joe Cogan, Sunday at 3 p.m. outside Lefferts Homestead Children's Historic House Museum, Prospect Park, close to the intersection of Flatbush Avenue and Empire Boulevard. Free. After the concert visitors can explore the house and its gardens (open 1 to 5 p.m.) or take a spin on the carousel, with its 51 colorful horses and fire-breathing dragons at 50 cents a ride. Information: (718) 965-6505.

''FOUNDING FATHER'S DAY.'' Families can celebrate Father's Day on Sunday from noon to 4 p.m. with programs about Rufus King, Revolutionary War major, and tours of the King Manor Museum, King Park, Jamaica Avenue between 150th and 153rd Streets, Jamaica, Queens. Admission: $2; $1 for children. Information: (718) 206-0545.

''PARSLEY, SAGE, ROSEMARY AND THYME.'' A tour of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine's grounds, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, home to plants, flowers and herbs, tomorrow from 10 a.m. at noon. For children 4 and older. Fee: $5. Reservations: (212) 932-7347.

''POPPIES FOR POPPY.'' After viewing the big, round poppy buds at Wave Hill, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx, youngsters can create poppy designs with special crayons to transfer to cloth or fabric as a Father's Day gift. Tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m. Each participant should bring a T-shirt, a tie or other textile. Free with admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; Saturdays, free until noon. Information: (718) 549-3200; reservations: extension 213.

NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY EVENTS tomorrow at Manhattan branches. Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53rd Street, (212) 621-0618 or (212) 621-0636, at 3 p.m., ''Meet the Author-Illustrator: Chris Conover,'' who will qdraw pictures and talk about his new book, ''The Lion's Share.'' For ages 4 to 8. The Yorkville Branch, 222 East 79th Street, (212) 744-5824, will offer ''Elementary Vaudeville,'' a solo play by Jami Simon about growing up, including participation by the audience, ages 4 and older, who will read, sing and dance along. Free.

''THE TRAVELS OF BABAR: AN ADVENTURE IN SCALES,'' an hourlong musical based on the story by Jean de Brunhoff about the adventures of King Babar and Queen Celeste, featuring a score by the American composer Raphael Mostel. The program, directed by Mr. Mostel, features a digital slide show of images of the original de Brunhoff illustrations, and narration by Anne Jackson and Eli Wallach. Tomorrow at 1, 5 and 7:30 p.m.; Sunday at 1 and 5 p.m.; Monday at 7:30 p.m. Monday's performance is in French. Florence Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street. Tickets: $20. Reservations: (212) 307-4100.
Zoos

''DOLPHIN DOO-WOP,'' a 1950's-style party tomorrow and Sunday featuring dolphins, sea lions, beluga whales and sea otters, along with face painting, antique cars and storytelling. New York Aquarium, West Eighth Street and the Boardwalk, Coney Island, Brooklyn. Free with aquarium admission. Admission: $9.75; the elderly and children 2 to 12, $6; under 2, free. Information: (718) 265-3474.

WATER WONDERS. A family program on the importance of water to all living creatures. Staten Island Zoo, 614 Broadway, off Forest Avenue, West Brighton, Sunday from 10:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. For children 5 and older. Lunch, water squirters and program free with zoo admission: $3; children 3 to 11, $2; under 3, free. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 4:45 p.m. Information: (718) 442-3101.

Correction: June 17, 2000, Saturday A children's activity entry in the Spare Times listing of Weekend yesterday for ''Water Wonders,'' a family program with lunch from 10:30 to 12:30 tomorrow at the Staten Island Zoo, misstated the admission. It is $40 for a group of four people, and children must be 5 or older and be accompanied by an adult; it is not free with zoo admission. Registration: (718) 442-3101.
Correction: June 17, 2000, Saturday

A children's activity entry in the Spare Times listing of Weekend yesterday for ''Water Wonders,'' a family program with lunch from 10:30 to 12:30 tomorrow at the Staten Island Zoo, misstated the admission. It is $40 for a group of four people, and children must be 5 or older and be accompanied by an adult; it is not free with zoo admission. Registration: (718) 442-3101.
